Award.AwardTitle: Programmable pattern transformation of reconfigurable polymer membranes
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project involves synthesizing polymeric materials that can respond to external stimuli by reconfiguring their shapes. These polymers will be processed so as to yield patterned microstructured membranes with regularly spaced holes. The study of structural change in response to external stimuli will provide important scientific insights into how to design reconfigurable nanomaterials. These could be used to create more complex, multifunctional microstructures. The resulting changes in physical properties (e.g. transparency and color change) may also make these materials relevant to novel technologies, including tunable optical windows, sensors, programmable sound and heat transfer, catalysis, drug delivery, and soft robotics. Students at all levels will be exposed to a diverse range of topics in chemistry, materials science and engineering, physics, soft mechanics, nanofabrication and computational modeling. Outreach will include underrepresented groups at local high schools and community colleges to carry out research on campus at the University of Pennsylvania. Research results will be showcased at the Philadelphia Materials Day and at other public outreach events.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project involves synthesis and study of microstructured polymer membranes that are responsive to external stimuli (e.g. pH, temperature and light), aimed at providing deeper understanding of the materials' mechanical responses in complex geometries (both isotropically and anisotropically). This in turn will allow for programming the evolution of complex chiral structures by considering the molecular structures of the polymers, the geometric parameters of the pore arrays in the membranes, and the application of external forces. Specifically, the research includes 1) preparation of a range of poly(2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate) (PHEMA) based hydrogel membranes with microscopic hole arrays of arbitrary feature size, spacing, aspect ratio, and arrangement; 2) examination of the solvent-swelling induced pattern transformation at different pH and temperature and its comparison to modeling; 3) synthesis of nematic liquid crystal monomers and crosslinkers to prepare microstructured nematic liquid crystal elastomers (NLCEs); 4) control of surface anchoring of the liquid crystal molecules within the membranes to maximize the strain response and comparison to modeling; 5) exploration of the internal instability in NLCE membranes at different temperatures in comparison to pattern transformation in PHEMA-based hydrogel membranes; 6) application of the same deformation principles to investigate light-responsive NLCE membranes with local spatial control of light and polarization.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania, Mat. Sci. & Eng Dept.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nature provides us with beautiful examples of intrinsic, bottom-up effects from the sunflowers, animal stripes, to fingerprints. In those systems, instabilities, packing constraints, and simple geometries drive the formation of delicate, detailed, and beautiful patterns spanning many lengthscales. This proposal seeks to synthesize responsive polymers and pattern them into various microstructures, followed by exposure to external stimuli (e.g. pH, temperature and light). The study of structural change in response to external stimuli will provide important scientific insights how to design reconfigurable polymeric soft materials to create complex two- (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) structures though programmable shape change from a microstructured 2D polymer film.

To achieve these goals, we

1) fabricated poly(2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate) (PHEMA) based pH and temperature responsive hydrogel membranes with microscopic hole arrays of arbitrary feature size, spacing, aspect ratio, and arrangement. While swelling of the square array hydrogel membranes led to ~ 50/50 mixture of right- and left-handed chiral structures, predominant single handedness with enantiomeric excess fraction > 95% was obtained from the oblique array of porous membranes. The study will offer insights of the origin of the single chirality in nature such as seen in sunflowers due to physical constraints.

2) designed and synthesized a series of photocrosslinkable LC monomers (LCMs) with precise alignment on surface (planar or perpendicular to), which is critical to actuate the smart materials, guide particle assembles, and to modular light (e.g. for liquid crystal displays). With the understanding, we explored deformation of microstructured nematic liquid crystal elastomers (NLCEs), a two-way shape memory polymers with an internal strain, including micropillar arrays and 2D sheets with pre-programmed LCM alignment. Upon heating above the nematic phase transition temperature, the 2D NLCE films formed a variety of 3D structures pre-programmed by the micropatterned one-dimensional (1D) channels laced within the 2D sheet. We showed that miniaturized LCE actuators offered very large area work capacities (~1.05 J/m2), lifting weights that are more than 700 times heavier than the actuator.

3) designed new photocrosslinking chemistry via thiol-acrylate click reactions, leading to rapid photocrosslinking within the micropatterns. In collaboration with Prof. Randall Kamien at Penn Physics, whose group theoretically designed the LC director fields, we successfully created various arbitrary shapes with positive and negative Gaussian curvatures, and their combinations (e.g. leaf and face) upon heating the films above the nematic phase transition temperature.

The research outcome has led to several publications and 1 patent filing, and numerous presentations at conferences (ACS, APS, MRS, and Liquid Crystal Gordon Research Conference) and invited departmental seminars. Students at all levels and the postdoc involved in the project have been exposed to a diverse range of topics in polymer science, liquid crystal physics, mechanical properties, materials science and engineering, and nano- and microfabrication techniques through new training and outreach opportunities, including REU activities, summer internship, independent study, senior design projects, science demonstrations at K-12 level, development of a new nano-/microfabrication lab course by the PI, and collaboration with research groups at Penn, Temple University, and Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST). New collaborations are under-development for drug delivery with industry and miniaturized, autonomous soft robots with robotics groups on Penn campus.

In the last 3 years, 2 PhD students (1 female), 1 postdoc fellow, 4 master students (self-supported, 1 female), and 7 undergraduate students (3 females, 2 URM) were involved in the proposed research. The two undergraduate senior design teams won the 1st prize of senior design competition in the Materials Science and Engineering Department at Penn in both Year 2016 and Year 2017. They learned about the nano- and microfabrication of structured polymers, integration with additives such as carbon nanotubes and dyes, use of paper as substrate, and characterization of crosslinking reactions, modulus and responses. Importantly, through research they developed deeper understanding of polymer chemistry, surface chemistry, and liquid crystal physics, and how to combine them to design novel responsive materials.

The dramatic shape change and physical properties will serve as the keystone to novel technologies, including tunable optical windows, sensors, programmable sound and heat transfer, catalysis, drug delivery, and soft robotics.


Last Modified: 07/21/2017
Modified by: Shu Yang

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Nature provides us with beautiful examples of intrinsic, bottom-up effects from the sunflowers, animal stripes, to fingerprints. In those systems, instabilities, packing constraints, and simple geometries drive the formation of delicate, detailed, and beautiful patterns spanning many lengthscales. This proposal seeks to synthesize responsive polymers and pattern them into various microstructures, followed by exposure to external stimuli (e.g. pH, temperature and light). The study of structural change in response to external stimuli will provide important scientific insights how to design reconfigurable polymeric soft materials to create complex two- (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) structures though programmable shape change from a microstructured 2D polymer film. While swelling of the square array hydrogel membranes led to ~ 50/50 mixture of right- and left-handed chiral structures, predominant single handedness with enantiomeric excess fraction > 95% was obtained from the oblique array of porous membranes.
